Technical Assistance Report
 
Project Number: 44484  
Regional—Capacity Development Technical Assistance (R-CDTA) 
December 2010 
 
 
 
Capacity Building for Financial Institutions, Phase 2
 
 
The views expressed herein are those of the consultant and do not necessarily represent those of ADB’s 
members, Board of Directors, Management, or staff, and may be preliminary in nature.

Vice-President  L. Venkatachalam, Private Sector and Cofinancing Operations 
Director General  P. Erquiaga, Private Sector Operations Department (PSOD) 
Director  R. van Zwieten, Capital Markets and Financial Sectors Division, PSOD 
   
Team leader  P. Bracey, Principal Investment Specialist, PSOD 
Team member  N. Moller, Counsel, Office of the General Counsel 
 
In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  In  July  2006,  the  Board  of  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  approved  a  regional 
technical assistance (TA) in the amount of $1.35 million to build financial institution capacity.1 The 
TA aimed to strengthen and deepen the capacity of financial institutions in which ADB makes 
private  sector  investments  by  supporting  their  development  in  four  key  areas:  (i)  corporate 
governance,  (ii)  anti-money  laundering  and  anticorruption,  (iii)  environmental  and  social 
management system efforts, and (iv) financing strategies for small and medium-sized enterprises 
(SMEs). As structured, the TA allowed ADB flexibility in offering customized support to individual 
financial institutions through the provision of assistance in any or all of the above key areas. The 
proceeds  of  the  TA  were  effectively  used  to  strengthen  and  deepen  the  capacity  of  several 
financial institutions. Such activities included supporting the development of the operational risk 
management procedures and SME financing strategies for one bank in the People’s Republic of 
China,  strengthening  the  anti-money-laundering  policies  of  another  bank  and  building  an 
environmental management system for a third bank in that country. Proceeds from the TA were 
also used to assist a bank in Afghanistan in (i) strengthening its anti-money-laundering processes 
and procedures, (ii) building its environmental and social management system, and (iii) developing 
its SME financing strategies.  
 
2.  As mentioned in the TA completion report, the overall assessment of the TA was successful. 
The design enabled each financial institution to receive exactly the type of technical assistance 
required in an expedited manner. Also, having the project planning and coordination committee at 
the financial institution proved critical in managing the process and ensuring that the TA content 
was tailored to the needs of the institution. Changes recommended by the consultants were in 
large part implemented by all the institutions; however, it is acknowledged that the institutions may 
need to make more changes to fully meet international best practices.  
 
3.  Based on the successful utilization of this first TA, ADB would like to establish a new 
regional facility in the amount of $1.12 million to provide timely technical assistance to eligible 
financial institutions in the above-mentioned and certain other areas, and in doing so increase the 
development impact of ADB’s interventions. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 
1.2 In consideration of lessons learned during the first TA, some selection criteria will be adjusted in 
this TA. As this TA was not included in any country partnership strategy or country operations 
business plan, concept approval was obtained from all relevant vice-presidents on 29 November 
2010. 
II.  ISSUES 
4.  ADB financial institution interventions via its private sector window include (i) the filling of 
market gaps through creation of new institutions; (ii) the provision of regulatory capital (equity, 
subordinated debt, other capital instruments) to key institutions to support capital ratios and asset 
expansion; (iii) the provision of funding (e.g., additional liquidity, longer tenors, foreign or domestic 
currencies) to key institutions to expand assets and improve asset–liability management; and (iv) 
targeted onlending programs to priority sectors such as microfinance, SMEs, leasing, infrastructure, 
housing,  trade  finance,  and  clean  energy  (via  debt  facilities  and  partial  credit  guarantees). 
Interventions  can  take  the  form  of  lending  (e.g.,  loans,  bonds),  equity  investments,  hybrid 
instruments (e.g., preferred stock, subordinated debt, convertible debt), partial credit and political 
risk guarantees, and other suitable instruments.   
 
5.  The financial institutions with which ADB chooses to work are high-potential entities that 
would benefit from financial assistance and strategic and operational improvements provided by 
ADB as part of an ongoing effort to increase know-how transfer and capacity building. In line with 
                                                 
1  ADB. 2006. Technical Assistance for Capacity Building for Financial Institutions. Manila. (TA 6332–REG). 
2  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of the ADB’s website on 15 December 2010.

2   
its  Strategy  20203 and  the  various  financial  sector  road  maps  and  country  strategies,  ADB 
prioritized four areas of such capacity building: (i) corporate governance and internal controls; (ii) 
anti-money-laundering,  anti-terrorism,  and  anticorruption  efforts;  (iii)  environmental  and  social 
safeguards;  and  (iv)  microfinance,  SMEs,  housing,  infrastructure,  and  clean  energy  financing 
strategies. The underdevelopment of these aspects of operation by financial institutions in ADB’s 
developing member countries constrains their business on several levels: 
(i)  Corporate governance and internal controls. Poor corporate governance in the areas of 
risk management and internal controls may take the form of non-transparent audit results, 
lack  of  independence  of  audit  or  risk  management  functions,  inappropriate  credit 
assignment authority, etc. All of these can lead to difficulties in meeting listing requirements 
for initial public offerings, attracting strategic investors, and engaging in other activities likely 
for growing companies.   
(ii) Anti-money-laundering, anti-terrorism, and anticorruption efforts. Financial institutions 
often  face  potential  problems  with  money  laundering,  corruption,  and  fraud  that  could 
damage them and generate perceived risk among depositors and investors, undermining 
the customer trust that is essential for sound growth.4 
(iii) Environmental  and  social  safeguards.  Good  environmental  and  social  management 
systems and policies signal that a corporation will contribute to environmental and social 
safeguard protection, and is also dedicated to managing risks and opportunities intelligently 
while gaining a long-term competitive business advantage in the market.  The development 
and implementation of such systems and policies, however, can often prove challenging to 
undertake without outside expertise.    
(iv) Financing  strategies.  Although  the  market  has  huge  potential  for  many  financial 
institutions, it can often be difficult for them to determine the right strategies for penetrating 
or extending their reach into particular sectors, such as microfinance, SMEs, housing, 
infrastructure, and clean energy.  Even if they are active in these sectors, they may lack the 
proper risk management systems to engage responsibly in these activities.   
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Selection Criteria 
6.  The  TA  will  target  financial  institutions  that  are,  or  are  expected  to  become,  ADB’s 
borrowers and investees.  
7.  Country selection. The financial sector in each country has its own needs with respect to 
ADB’s private sector focus areas. The assessment of these needs, especially the analysis of a 
country’s financial sector for shortcomings, is based on various sources, including the country 
program strategy and private sector assessment, third-party research, and bespoke research. The 
specified needs will be customized within ADB’s private sector skill set, strategic themes, and focus 
areas, and will warrant different types of interventions.  
 
8.  Given the limited size of the TA, country selection was determined in line with the then-
current strategy of ADB’s Capital Markets and Financial Sectors Division (PSCM), and assistance 
was focused on private sector operations in certain key markets such as the People’s Republic of 
China, India, and the Philippines, with consideration given to other countries such as Indonesia, 
Kazakhstan, Pakistan, and Viet Nam. It is proposed that the new TA also follow PSCM’s strategic 
priorities, as well as those identified in the country program strategies. As detailed in the PSCM 
Business Plan and Priorities 2010–2012, there is greater emphasis on particular business lines 
and frontier countries. It is expected that this TA can be offered to financial institutions throughout 
the region.

4  B. Bartlett, 2002. The Negative Effects of Money Laundering on Economic Development. Manila: ADB.

9.  Individual financial institution selection. From a business perspective, ADB will seek to 
calibrate its interventions within an engagement spectrum that balances the variety of selected 
transactions with varying degrees of (i) commercial risk, (ii) financial return, (iii) development 
effectiveness, and (iv) opportunistic market demand. The goal of this approach is to achieve a 
sustainable  deal  flow  that  encompasses  robust  flow  transactions,  high-impact  but  higher-risk 
developmental deals, and responsive interventions by market-driven requests from ADB’s private 
sector partners.5 It is these criteria that will ultimately guide selection of the individual financial 
institutions eligible for intervention and the TA. 
 
10.  Most of ADB’s private sector business is based on direct requests to ADB from the private 
sector. However, ADB does also seek its own business origination by proposing to its private 
sector clients certain business opportunities. In addition, there is a certain amount of referral 
business from existing contacts, as well as other multilateral and bilateral development banks. 
Importantly, regardless of the channel used to select a particular financial institution (i.e., for ADB’s 
private sector intervention), ADB expects that the selected institution, once deemed fit for an ADB 
private sector investment, would also be assessed and deemed qualified to receive assistance (if 
required) under the criteria of this TA. 
 
11.  Under the first TA, preference was given to financial institutions in which ADB had made an 
equity investment, as opposed to those provided with ADB loans or guarantees. In order to extend 
the technical assistance to the institutions most in need, this TA will be agnostic to the modality of 
intervention and focus on the greatest level of financial sector development.  
B.  Impact and Outcome 
12.  Impact. The anticipated impact of the TA is to strengthen and deepen the capacity of 
financial institutions in which ADB makes private sector investments (equity, loans, guarantees) by 
improving  corporate  governance,  combating  money  laundering  and  corruption,  improving 
environment  and  social  safeguards,  and  boosting  penetration  into  the  microfinance,  SMEs, 
housing, infrastructure, and clean energy markets. These measures will help ensure that the 
impact of ADB’s private sector investments is as high as possible.  
 
13.  Each activity funded by this TA will have its own development impact framework and 
specific indicators. Such indicators will include (i) stronger corporate governance and internal 
controls,  (ii)  increased  ability  to  recognize  money-laundering  transactions,  (iii)  adoption  of  an 
environmental  and  social  management  system  in  compliance  with  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy 
Statement (2009), and (iv) development of suitable financing strategies.  
 
14.  Outcome. With the help of this TA, the capacity of selected financial institutions will be 
stronger and deeper in the specified areas as a result of strengthened policies, procedures, and 
strategies, thus improving their potential contributions to their respective financial sectors as well 
as their overall performance. 
 
15.  Outputs. The expected outputs will depend on and be tailored to the selected financial 
institution and intervention according to the needs of the institution, as specified jointly by the 
institution and ADB. However, any given TA will likely (i) review, formulate, and redraft the financial 
institution’s policies and procedures for corporate governance and internal controls, and conduct 
related  workshops;  (ii)  review,  formulate,  and  redraft  policies  and  procedures  against  money

increase the flow side of its business and the visibility of ADB and PSCM with respect to private sector development in 
the market. This will, in the long term, increase not only ADB’s market standing and acceptance, but also the impact of 
its  interventions,  i.e.,  ADB’s  development  impact.  This  approach  will  ensure  a  healthy  and  steady  stream  of 
transactions with a development impact, while bolstering ADB’s long-term market role and viability. Furthermore, 
PSCM seeks to convert developmental pilot transactions into replicable business models and products.

laundering, terrorism, and corruption, and conduct related training workshops; (iii) hold workshops 
on environmental and social safeguard training, and help formulate policies for such safeguards; 
and (iv) review, formulate, and redraft microfinance, SMEs, housing, infrastructure, and/or clean 
energy financing strategies. 
C.  Methodology and Key Activities 
16.  The methodology and key activities of the TA will depend on the specific institution and 
intervention proposed. However, likely activities and sub-activities will include: 
(i)  Corporate governance and internal controls. Funding would be used to 
(a) provide training to senior staff on general corporate governance issues; 
(b) advise management on internationally accepted best practices for internal controls;  
(c) examine  the  financial  institution’s  organizational  structure,  particularly  the  extent  of 
separation of managerial roles and responsibilities between various departments and 
risk management groups or committees; assess whether sufficient safeguards exist to 
ensure effective internal controls and oversight; 
(d) report  on  observations  and  recommendations  based  on  best  practices,  including 
recommending amendments or changes to internal control policies and procedures, and 
streamlining current systems; and 
(e) help revise the internal control policies and procedures. 
(ii) Anti-money-laundering, anti-terrorism, and anticorruption efforts. Funding would be 
used to: 
(a) review  and  assess  current  anti-money-laundering,  anti-terrorism,  and  anticorruption 
policies and procedures; 
(b) report  on  observations  and  recommendations  based  on  best  practices,  including 
recommending amendments or changes to anti-money-laundering, anti-terrorism, and 
anticorruption policies and procedures, and streamlining current systems;  
(c) help revise the anti-money-laundering, anti-terrorism, and anticorruption policies and 
procedures; 
(d) design trainings and undertake a workshop on anti-money-laundering, anti-terrorism, 
and anticorruption awareness and safeguards; and 
(e) help management decide how to approach technology enablement and/or support for 
suspicious-transaction  reporting  and  know-your-customer  processes  with  respect  to 
anti-money-laundering efforts. 
(iii) Environmental and social management system. Funding would be used to: 
(a) develop  and  conduct  a  workshop  on  environmental  issues  and  safeguard  training. 
Outputs could include: training curriculum and materials; better understanding and skills 
of  workshop  participants  in  identifying  and  managing  environmental  risks;  greater 
awareness of business opportunities for sustainability of products and services; and 
greater  awareness  of  workshop  participants  of  national  environmental  safeguard 
policies and requirements. 
(b) Assist in developing and drafting an environmental and social management system in 
compliance with national laws and regulations. 
(iv) Financing strategies. Funding would be used to 
(a) review available financing products for microfinance, SMEs, housing, infrastructure, 
and/or clean energy; 
(b) review the regulatory environment; 
(c) review  financing  and  product  needs  of  the  customer  base  and  potential  customer 
segments; 
(d) provide  international  benchmarks  for  microfinance,  SMEs,  housing,  infrastructure, 
and/or clean energy financing and products, and risk mitigation and concerns;

5
(e) develop financing strategies for microfinance, SMEs, housing, infrastructure, and/or 
clean energy; and 
(f)  help develop financing products that would expand the institution’s offerings. 
D.  Cost and Financing 
17.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1,120,000 equivalent. The TA will be financed on a 
grant basis from ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF IV). The cost estimates and 
financing plan are in Appendix 2. It should be noted that the cost of implementing the suggested 
recommendations pursuant to the TA will be borne by the selected financial institution. In other 
words, ADB will undertake a gap analysis, for instance of anti-money-laundering efforts, review 
policies and procedures, and advise the institution on the next steps. The institution will then install 
new information technology systems at its own cost based on the analysis undertaken by ADB. 
ADB will seek reimbursement of the TA out of ensuing assistance, to the extent possible. 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
18.  The TA will be executed and implemented by ADB, with the Private Sector Operations 
Department (PSOD) as the focal point. ADB, through PSOD, will be responsible for all technical 
implementation issues. Disbursements under the TA will be made in accordance with ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). The TA will 
be implemented over 48 months from the start date, coinciding with the approval date of the TA. 
 
19.  Pursuant to the guidelines detailed in ADB’s Operations Manual on TA,6 any activity under 
the TA will begin only after receiving a no-objection letter from the government of the country in 
which the financial institution is located. 
 
20.  The TA activities will be implemented with the help of international and national consultants 
and firms. The outline terms of reference for consultants is in Appendix 3. The consultants for the 
corporate  governance  and  internal  controls  module,  and  for  the  anti-money-laundering,  anti-
terrorism, and anticorruption module will be engaged via the consultant qualification selection 
process in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from 
time to time). These modules will require 32 person-months of international consultant services.  
 
21.  The consultants for the environmental and social management system module, and the 
financing strategies module will be chosen as individual consultants in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants. Up to 16 individual consultants will be recruited to conduct 
the environmental and social management system and the financing strategies modules. These 
modules will entail 10 person-months of national individual and 36 person-months of international 
individual consultant services. 
 
22.  ADB  and  each  TA  recipient  will  form  a  project  planning  and  coordination  committee, 
comprising  representatives  at  appropriate  levels  from  the  financial  institution  and  ADB.  The 
coordination  committee  will  organize  regular  consultative  meetings  and  a  final  dissemination 
workshop followed by discussions of the findings. The institution will nominate officers and senior 
managers for the training component related to environmental and social safeguards. (Appendix 4 
presents further details on this training component.)  
IV. THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION

10  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Risk Management and Internal Control 
 
1.  International firms will be recruited that have high-level qualifications and significant 
experience in evaluating operations risk management and internal controls to ensure that the 
proper internal oversight structures are in place. One international firm will be selected for each 
engagement with a given financial institution (institution) through the Consultant Qualification 
Selection process in accordance with the Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as 
amended from time to time). The firm will have prior experience on similar projects in financial 
institutions in the country in which the technical assistance (TA) is being employed. Each 
engagement will require approximately 4 international consultants intermittently for 2–6 person-
months, depending on the extent of the work needed for the given financial institution. Up to 4 
engagements for this module are estimated.  
 
2.  For each engagement, the firm will: 
(i)  Advise the institution and the Asian Development Bank (ADB) on internationally 
accepted best practices for risk management in commercial banks.  
(ii)  Support  ADB  in  reviewing  the  institution’s  policies  and  procedures  on  risk 
management and internal control. These will include the draft operations risk 
management (ORM) framework prepared by the institution, as well as other 
credit  policies  and,  in  particular,  the  critical  components  and  methodology.  
Evaluate which areas in the ORM framework and policies, in their current form, 
are acceptable and follow best practices. If the ORM framework and policies do 
not follow best practices, make initial recommendations on reorienting those 
areas in the framework to ensure best practices are in place. 
(iii)  Assess  the  internal  controls  outlined  in  the  ORM  framework  and  determine 
whether they are sufficient and properly integrated into the ORM framework. 
(iv)  Examine the organizational structure, and particularly the extent of separation of 
managerial roles and responsibilities between the various departments and risk 
management  groups  or  committees.  Assess  whether  there  are  sufficient 
safeguards to ensure adequate internal controls and oversight. 
(v)  Based  on  the  above,  and  in  light  of  best  practices,  prepare  a  report  on 
observations and recommendations. The report should include recommendations 
on  amending  or  changing  the  ORM  framework,  including  key  definitions, 
streamlining of the current system, etc. 
(vi)  Provide advice, contacts, and coordination support for the international training 
component (if necessary). 
 
B.  Anti-Money-Laundering, Anti-Terrorism, and Anticorruption Efforts  
 
3.  International firms will be recruited for this module. One international firm will be selected 
for each engagement with an institution through the Consultant Qualification Selection process 
in line with the ADB guidelines. The engagement will require approximately 4 international 
consultants intermittently for approximately 3 person-months. Up to 4 engagements for this 
module are estimated.

4.  For each engagement, the firm will: 
(i)  Advise the institution and ADB on internationally accepted best practices for anti-
money-laundering, anti-terrorism, and anticorruption efforts in commercial banks.  
(ii)  Assess  the  current  anti-money-laundering,  anti-terrorism  and  anticorruption 
policies and procedures. Evaluate which areas in the policies and procedures are 
acceptable and follow best practices in their current form. If the policies and 
procedures  do  not  follow  best  practices,  make  initial  recommendations  on 
reorienting those areas to ensure best practices are in place. 
(iii)  Based  on  the  above,  and  in  light  of  best  practices,  prepare  a  report  on 
observations and recommendations. The report should include recommendations 
on  amending  or  changing  the  anti-money-laundering,  anti-terrorism  and 
anticorruption policies and procedures. 
(iv)  Provide advice, contacts, and coordination support for the international training 
component, and coordinating support as needed. 
  
C.  Environmental and Social Safeguards Consultant 
5.  Up to 10 individual national consultants will be selected for this module in accordance 
with the ADB guidelines. Up to two consultants will be selected for each engagement with a 
given institution for approximately 1 person-month. 
 
6.  For each engagement, the consultant(s) will undertake the following tasks (for a more 
detailed training outline, please refer to Appendix 4): 
(i)  advise the institution on internationally accepted best practices for environmental 
awareness and safeguards in commercial banks;  
(ii)  provide  advice,  contacts,  and  coordinating  support,  as  needed,  for  the 
international training component; and 
(iii)  assist in drafting an environmental and social management system in compliance 
with ADB’s environmental and social safeguards policies. 
 
D.  Financing Strategies 
7.  Up to 6 individual international consultants will be selected for this module in accordance 
with the ADB guidelines. Up to two consultants will be selected for each engagement with a 
given institution for approximately 6 person-months intermittently.   
 
8.  For each engagement, the consultant(s) will 
(i)  review  existing  microfinance,  small  and  medium-sized  enterprises  (SMEs), 
housing, infrastructure, and /or clean energy financing products;  
(ii)  review financing and product needs of the customer base and assess other 
potential customer segments;  
(iii)  provide international benchmarks for microfinance, SMEs, housing, infrastructure, 
and/or clean energy financing and relevant products, risk mitigation and concerns;  
(iv)  develop  a  microfinance,  SMEs,  housing,  infrastructure,  and/or  clean  energy 
financing strategy; and  
(v)  assist in the design of missing financing products.

12  Appendix 3 
E.  Reporting Arrangements 
9.  The firm will be responsible for preparing, as required, (i) brief monthly progress reports 
with updates on implementation until the project is completed; and (ii) a draft final report 2 
weeks before completion of the tasks under the respective TA component. The draft final report 
will be revised and resubmitted upon receiving comments from ADB and the institution.

Appendix 4  13 
ENVIRONMENTAL AND SOCIAL SAFEGUARDS TRAINING COMPONENT 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
1.  The  objectives  of  the  regional  technical  assistance  (TA)  are  to  assist  the  financial 
institution (the institution) in achieving sustainable environmental and social development goals. 
Toward that end, the purpose of the TA is to strengthen the institution’s capacity to manage 
environmental and social impact risks in its financial transactions, and to comply with national 
safeguard policies and requirements. 
 
2.  The  TA’s  expected  outputs  under  the  environmental  and  social  safeguards  training 
component include (i) a training curriculum and materials reflecting the institution’s needs; (ii) 
stronger  understanding  and  skills  of  workshop  participants  in  identifying  and  managing 
environmental risks, along with better awareness of business opportunities for sustainability 
products and services; (iii) greater awareness of workshop participants of the environmental 
safeguard policies and requirements of the Asian Development Bank (ADB); and (iv) stronger 
capacity to design a social and environmental management system tailored to the institution in 
compliance with national safeguard laws and regulations, and ADB policies. 
 
B.  Preliminary  Outline  of  Training  Seminar  on  Environmental  and  Social 
Considerations in Financial Transactions of the Financial Institution 
 
3.  The duration of the seminar is one day, and the number of participants is about 20–25. 
 
4.  Background  of  participants.  Credit  officers  with  underwriting  responsibility  in  the 
financial institution’s credit review process. Participants must be in managerial positions so that 
they have the possibility of disseminating the seminar content to other financial institution staff. 
 
5.  Outputs and outcomes. These will include:  
(i)  Outputs. About 20–25 participants undergo the training; presentation materials. 
(ii)  Outcomes.  The  participants  gain  a  better  understanding  and  knowledge  of 
environmental and social risks and opportunities in financial transactions. 
 
6.  Suggested outline. This will include:  
 
(i)  Session  1:  The  environmental  and  social  issues  in  the  institution’s 
transactions  (about  1  hour).  The  presentation  will  aim  to  answer  why  the 
institution needs to consider environmental and social aspects in its business. It 
will cover environmental and social risks and opportunities in the institution’s 
transactions, with examples of environmental and social risks. 
 
(ii)  Session 2: Laws, regulations, and standards on environmental assessment 
(about  3  hours).  The  speakers  will  give  an  overview  of  specific  national 
environmental regulations and their implications for the institution’s business. 
These include 
(a)  risks  for  and  obligations  of  lenders  under  national  environmental  and 
other regulations and laws with respect to environmental issues; 
(b)  national  requirements  for  environmental  assessment  of  greenfield 
projects and refinancing of existing projects;

14  Appendix 4 
 
(c)  requirements  for  environmental  assessment  and  implications  for 
corporate lending;  
(d)  environmental  risks  and  their  assessment  in  other  banking  areas, 
e.g., retail, asset management, capital markets, advisory; and 
(e)  implications for the institution’s business. 
  
(iii)  Session 3: ADB’s approach to environmental assessment (about 1 hour). 
The speaker will cover ADB’s environmental requirements as applied to ADB-
financed  projects,  benchmark  ADB’s  standards  to  those  of  other  financial 
institutions (e.g., GE Capital in the United States) and the Equator Principles, and 
reference them to national policies.  
 
(iv)  Session 4: Concepts and principles of environmental management and an 
environmental management system, as well as environmental management 
practices in selected financial institutions (2 hours). The presentation will 
(a) cover  the  concepts  and  principles  of  environmental  management  and  an 
environmental  management  system  in  financial  institutions,  and  (b)  provide 
examples and case studies of such systems and practices in selected financial 
institutions. The presentation will show clearly how an environment management 
system should work in a financial institution while referencing this to the particular 
institution’s own regulatory and business environment, as well as to the context 
of its businesses (e.g., retail, corporate). 
 
(v)  Session 5: Next steps (1.5 hours). The speaker will present ideas on the next 
steps  that  the  institution  should  take  toward  institutionalizing  environmental 
management in its organization. This session will be used as an open forum for 
the participants to give their views and suggestions regarding those next steps. 
 
C.  Evaluation of Training Seminar 
 
7.  The training seminar will be evaluated as follows: 
 
(i)  Measures of the efficiency aspect. These will include 
(a)  performance of the speakers (observations and participants’ evaluations), 
(b)  participation of the participants in the open discussion (observation), 
(c)  percentage of participants attending all sessions (records), 
(d)  satisfaction of the participants (participants’ evaluations), and 
(e)  punctuality of the presentation and participants (observation and records). 
 
(ii)  Measures of the outcome or effectiveness aspect. These will include 
(a)  Method. A structured questionnaire and interviews of randomly selected 
participants. 
(b)  Benchmark.  Knowledge  and  understanding  of  the  participants  of  the 
subject before the seminar. This should be done in due course before the 
seminar using a well-structured questionnaire.   
(c)  Rating of seminar
